case_name: R. B. Bansilal Abirchand Mills v. Labour Court

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 2136 and 2295 of 1966 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 2136 and 2295 of 1966. Appeals from the judgment

facts.text: Appeals from judgment and order dated February 2, 1965 of Bombay High Court, Nagpur Bench in Special Civil Applications Nos. 246 of 1964 and 84 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated February 2, 1965 of the Bombay High Court, Nagpur Bench in Special Civil Applications Nos. 246 of 1964 and 84 of 1963 respectively.

facts.text: Appellant in C.A. No. 2136 of 1966 is a limited company under liquidation.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant in the first appeal is a limited companypany which is number under liquidation while the appellant in the second is a partnership firm, the respondents

facts.text: Appellant in C.A. No. 2295 of 1966 is a partnership firm.

anchor.surface_text: limited companypany which is number under liquidation while the appellant in the second is a partnership firm, the respondents in the two appeals being the Labour Court

facts.text: There was a textile mill known as R. B. Bansilal Abirchand Mills in Hinganghat employing about 1000 men.

anchor.surface_text: The facts are as follows. In Hinganghat there was a textile mill known as R. B. Bansilal Abirchand Mills which used to employ about 1000 men.

facts.text: The mill was owned by the firm, the appellant in the second appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The mill was owned by the firm, the appellant in the Second appeal.

facts.text: A fire broke out in the mill on March 27, 1959 causing appreciable damage to some of the machines.

anchor.surface_text: A fire broke out in the mill on March 27, 1959 doing appreciable damage to some of the machines.

facts.text: Employers put up a notice under Standing Order No. 19 on March 28, 1959 stating fire caused heavy loss and extensive damage rendering mills working impracticable until repairs.

anchor.surface_text: The employers put up a numberice under their Standing Order No. 19 on March 28, 1959 to the effect that the fire of the previous night had caused heavy loss and extensive damage to the departments rendering the mills working impracticable until necessary repairs and adjustments were carried out.

facts.text: Notice stated folding and workshop departments would continue to work as usual.

anchor.surface_text: The employees were however to numbere that the folding and workshop departments would companytinue to work as usual and numberice of resumption of mills working would be posted after necessary adjustment and repairs were carried out.

facts.text: Second notice issued on April 2, 1959 stating over 60 per cent of machines in carding, fly frame and ring frame departments damaged.

anchor.surface_text: This was followed by a second numberice issued on April 2, 1959 to the effect that the pre- liminary survey of the fire have in companyjunction with the insurance companypanies had shown that over 60 per cent of the machines in the carding. fly frame and Ring frame departments had been damaged

facts.text: Management declared stoppage of work of all productive departments.

anchor.surface_text: and that the damage to the bulk of these machines was such that they might require companyplete replacement. It was further announced that in the circumstances the Management had numberalternative but to declare stoppage of work of all the productive departments of the mills.

facts.text: Hukumchand Insurance Company Ltd. letter dated August 28, 1959 stated loss to buildings, machinery and accessories at Rs. 22,624/- .

anchor.surface_text: Although it is number possible to be precise as to the extent of the damage caused, a fair idea of it can be had from a letter of Hukumchand Insurance Company Ltd. dated August 28, 1959 stating that the loss to buildings, machinery and accessories had been determined at Rs. 22,624/- by the surveyors.

facts.text: On 27th April 1960, insurance companies agreed to re-assessment increasing repairs to Rs. 37,420/- .

anchor.surface_text: It appears that on 27th April 1960 the representatives of the insurance companypanies had agreed to re- assessment increasing the figure for repairs to Rs. 37,420/- .

facts.text: Third notice by firm on April 29, 1960 gave no indication of date of completion of repairs.

anchor.surface_text: The third numberice put up by the firm on April 29, 1960 gave numberindication of the date of companypletion of the repairs.

facts.text: On September 13, 1960 firm notified departments expected to commence working on or about 30th September, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: On September 13, 1960 the firm numberified that the departments of the mills which had remained unproductive since 28th March, 1959 were expected to companymence working on or about 30th September, 1960.

facts.text: Firm transferred mill to company incorporated on 8th December, 1959 for Rs. 34,75,000/- .

anchor.surface_text: The firm did number however work the mills in terms of the last numberice but transferred the same to the companypany which had been incorporated on 8th December, 1959. It appears that the companysideration for the transfer was Rs. 34,75,000/- made up of Rs. 11,50,000/- being the value of the immovable properties and Rs. 23,25,000/- being the value of movable properties.

facts.text: Towards end of 1961 and beginning of 1962, respondents 2 to 346 in CA 2295 presented applications under s.33C(2) to Labour Court Nagpur claiming lay-off from 28th March 1959 to 30th September 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Towards the end of 1961 and the be-inning of 1962, respon- dents 2 to 346 in Civil Appeal No. 2295 of 1966 presented applications under s. 33-C 2  of the Industrial Disputes Act to the Labour Court at Nagpur claiming to have been laid-off from 28th March 1959 to 30th September, 1960.

facts.text: Labour Court by order dated 30th November 1962 rejected preliminary objection as to jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: By order dated 30th November, 1962 the preliminary objection as to jurisdiction of the employers was rejected by the Labour Court.

facts.text: Bombay High Court by common judgment on 25th August 1962 rejected contentions that claim not maintainable and held Labour Court competent to adjudicate.

anchor.surface_text: On this, the appellants preferred an application under Art. 226 of the Constitution of India before, the Bombay High Court. By a companymon judgment rendered on 25th August, 1962 the High Court rejected the companytentions of the appellants that the claim under the Industrial Disputes Act was number maintainable because of the operation of the State Act and further held that the Labour Court was companypetent to adjudicate on the merits of the claim of the workers even where the employer disputed number only the jurisdiction of the said companyrt but also disputed that there was any lay-off as claimed and that the applicants were number workmen within the meaning of the Act.

facts.text: Labour Court on November 30, 1962 dismissed 125 applications as barred by res judicata.

anchor.surface_text: By order dated November 30, 1962 the Labour Court dismissed as barred by the principles of res judicata 125 applications of some of the workers who had previously applied to the Labour Court at Bombay and whose applications had been subsequently dismissed by the Labour Judge, Bombay on the ground of lack of jurisdiction under s. 33-C of the Industrial Disputes Act.

facts.text: Labour Court by order dated February 29, 1964 held there was lay-off and entitled to compensation for 18 months but badli workers not entitled.

anchor.surface_text: The Labour Court held by order dated February 29, 1964 that there had been a lay-off within the meaning of s. 2 kkk  of the Industrial Disputes Act and that the employees were entitled to companypensation for the full period of 18 months but workers who were badli workers were number entitled to such companypensation.

facts.text: Bombay High Court by common judgment on February 2, 1965 remanded matters to Labour Court for evidence on whether applicants presented themselves for work under s.25E(ii).

anchor.surface_text: The two writ petitions were disposed of by the High Court by a companymon judgment on February 2, 1965. ... In the result the High Court remanded the matters back to the Labour Court for recording fresh evidence on behalf of both the parties on the following issue Do the applicants prove that they presented themselves for work at the appointed time at least once a day within the meaning of s. 25- E ii ?

facts.text: Employers contended there was closure, not lay-off.

anchor.surface_text: The substantial point of Mr. Gupte appearing for one set of appellants was that it being the case of the employers that there had been a closure of the mills the dispute companyld number be adjudicated upon by a Labour Court

facts.text: Supreme Court held Labour Court had jurisdiction under s.33C(2) to entertain lay-off compensation applications.

anchor.surface_text: We find ourselves unable to accept Mr. Guptes companytention. ... the Labour Court was within its jurisdiction to entertain the applications

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeals fail and are dismissed with companyts.
under Art. 226 of the Constitution of India before, the Bombay High Court.

issues.text: whether the Labour Court had jurisdiction to entertain the application for lay-off compensation under s. 33-C(2) of the Industrial Disputes Act

anchor.surface_text: The main question in these two appeals by certificate is, whether the Labour Court had jurisdiction to entertain the application for lay-off compensation under s. 33-C 2  of the Industrial Disputes Act. The appellant in the first appeal is a limited company which is now under liquidation while the appellant in the second is a partnership firm, the respondents in the two appeals being the Labour Court and different groups of workmen.

issues.text: Whether having regard to the circumstances and the established facts there had been a lay-off within the meaning of the expression in s. 2(kkk)?

anchor.surface_text: Before the High Court four main points were raised, namely Whether having regard to the circumstances and the established facts there had been a lay-off within the meaning of the expression in s. 2 kkk ? If there had been a lay-off, whether compensation under s. 25-C read with S. 25-E of the Act was payable to the workers,

issues.text: If there had been a lay-off, whether compensation under s. 25-C read with S. 25-E of the Act was payable to the workers, also whether the workers were not entitled to compensation because of non-fulfilment of conditions prescribed in S. 25-E?

anchor.surface_text: If there had been a lay-off, whether compensation under s. 25-C read with S. 25-E of the Act was payable to the workers, also whether the workers were not entitled to compensation because of non-fulfilment of conditions prescribed in S. 25-E ? Whether badli workers were entitled to lay-off compensation? and Whether the quantum of compensation would be governed by the first proviso to S. 25-C or whether s. 25-C ii  would be applicable entitling the workers to compensation for the full period of the lay-off i.e. 28-3-59 to 30-9-1960 ?

issues.text: Whether badli workers were entitled to lay-off compensation?

anchor.surface_text: Whether badli workers were entitled to lay-off compensation? and Whether the quantum of compensation would be governed by the first proviso to S. 25-C or whether s. 25-C ii  would be applicable entitling the workers to compensation for the full period of the lay-off i.e. 28-3-59 to 30-9-1960 ? On the first question the High Court held that by every indication and circumstance and by express declaration of its management it was a running industry,

issues.text: Whether the quantum of compensation would be governed by the first proviso to S. 25-C or whether s. 25-C(ii) would be applicable entitling the workers to compensation for the full period of the lay-off i.e. 28-3-59 to 30-9-1960?

anchor.surface_text: and Whether the quantum of compensation would be governed by the first proviso to S. 25-C or whether s. 25-C ii  would be applicable entitling the workers to compensation for the full period of the lay-off i.e. 28-3-59 to 30-9-1960 ? On the first question the High Court held that by every indication and circumstance and by express declaration of its management it was a running industry, meaning thereby that there was no closure.

issues.text: whether the decision of the High Court in 1962 operated as res judicata in the present appeals

anchor.surface_text: Before us learned counsel for the respondents Mr. Bhandare sought to resist the main contention of the appellants by urging that the decision of the High Court in 1962 operated as res judicata in the present appeals. He said that it was open to the appellants to challenge the conclusion of the High Court arrived at in 1962 by moving the High Court by an application for the issue of a certificate of fitness for appeal to this Court

issues.text: Do the applicants prove that they presented themselves for work at the appointed time at least once a day within the meaning of s. 25-E(ii)?

anchor.surface_text: In the result the High Court remanded the matters back to the Labour Court for recording fresh evidence on behalf of both the parties on the following issue Do the applicants prove that they presented themselves for work at the appointed time at least once a day within the meaning of s. 25- E ii ?

issues.text: whether compensation is claimable only in terms of the Standing Orders of the Mill or under Chapter V-A

anchor.surface_text: It turned down the contention that compensation was claimable only in terms of the Standing Orders of the Mill. In the result the High Court remanded the matters back to the Labour Court for recording fresh evidence on behalf of both the parties on the following issue Do the applicants prove that they presented themselves for work at the appointed time at least once a day within the meaning of s. 25- E ii ? On the applications of the appellants, the High Court granted certificates under Art. 133 1   a  of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Labour Court had no jurisdiction under s.33C(2) because parties had to work out rights under State Act (C.P. and Berar Industrial Disputes Settlement Act, 1947)

anchor.surface_text: The appellants in the second appeal filed a written statement before the Labour Court contending inter alia that the Labour Court had no jurisdiction under s. 33-C 2  and that the parties had to work out their rights within the four corners of the State Act i.e. the C.P. and Berar Industrial Disputes Settlement Act, 1947.

arguments.court_response: Labour Court rejected preliminary objection; High Court rejected contention that claim not maintainable due to State Act

court_response_anchor.surface_text: numberjurisdiction under s. 33-C 2  and that the parties had to work out their rights within the four companyners of the State Act i.e. the C.P. and B

arguments.court_reasoning: Central ID Act applies for lay-off compensation; State Act does not bar

arguments.claim: Labour Court competent to adjudicate merits even if employer disputes jurisdiction, lay-off, and workman status

anchor.surface_text: By a common judgment rendered on 25th August, 1962 the High Court rejected the contentions of the appellants that the claim under the Industrial Disputes Act was not maintainable because of the operation of the State Act and further held that the Labour Court was competent to adjudicate on the merits of the claim of the workers even where the employer disputed not only the jurisdiction of the said court but also disputed that there was any lay-off as claimed and that the applicants were not workmen within the meaning of the Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: scope of s. 25-FFF of the Act. By issues 6 and 7 the appellant raised questions as to whether the closure had resulted in the retrenchment of the appl

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court affirms Labour Court jurisdiction

arguments.claim: 1962 High Court decision on jurisdiction operates as res judicata; appellants cannot challenge again

anchor.surface_text: Before us learned counsel for the respondents Mr. Bhandare sought to resist the main contention of the appellants by urging that the decision of the High Court in 1962 operated as res judicata in the present appeals.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: The respondent No. 2 put in an application before the Presiding, Officer, Labour Court Nagpur on 5th

arguments.court_reasoning: Court says not necessary to decide as matter disposed on merits

arguments.claim: Since employers case is closure of mills, dispute cannot be adjudicated by Labour Court but only by Industrial Tribunal under s.10(1)(d)

anchor.surface_text: The substantial point of Mr. Gupte appearing for one set of appellants was that it being the case of the employers that there had been a closure of the mills the dispute could not be adjudicated upon by a Labour Court and was entertainable only by an Industrial Tribunal under the provisions of s. 10 1   d  of the Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: scope of s. 25-FFF of the Act. By issues 6 and 7 the appellant raised questions as to whether the closure had resulted in the retrenchment of the appl

arguments.court_reasoning: Lay-off covered by Second Schedule item 6; Labour Court jurisdiction under s.7, s.10(1)(c); s.33C(2) for individual claims including incidental disputes

arguments.claim: Industrial dispute requires affecting class of employees; individual lay-off claims only if no prima facie closure

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Gupte drew our attention to various sections of the Act in support of his contention that an industrial dispute meant primarily a dispute or difference between employers on the one hand and employees on the other connected with the employment or non-employment or the terms of employment etc. of any person. He urged that the basic underlying idea was that to be an industrial dispute the dispute had to be one which affected the employee, as a class as pitted against their employers.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: scope of s. 25-FFF of the Act. By issues 6 and 7 the appellant raised questions as to whether the closure had resulted in the retrenchment of the appl

arguments.court_reasoning: Number of identical claims does not change nature to collective dispute; s.33C(2) covers individual statutory rights even if disputed

arguments.claim: In calamity affecting all employees wholesale, not lay-off under s.2(kkk) but closure

anchor.surface_text: He argued that individual workman could only approach the Labour Court for lay-off compensation when prima facie there was no question of closure of the industry by the employers and drew our attention to the definition of lay-off in s.2 kkk . According to him in a situation like the present where the inability on the part of the employer to give employment was not limited to a handful of persons but extended to the employees wholesale arising out of a calamity it could not be said that there had been a lay-off of the employees.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: one which arises under the statute itself and s 25-C provides for a benefit to the workman which is capable of being companyputed in terms of money u

arguments.court_reasoning: Notices indicate temporary stoppage, not closure; some departments continued; insignificant damage relative to value

arguments.claim: Chapter V-A individual claims only if no serious closure question requiring s.10(1)(d) reference; legislature intent via Schedules

anchor.surface_text: According to Mr. Gupte, Chapter V-A of the Act introduced in the year 1953 providing for claims being preferred by individual workmen to compensation could only be resorted to when the dispute was such as would not call for a reference under S. 10  1   d . He urged further that it being open to the Central Government to amend the Second and the Third Schedules by issue of notification under s. 40 of the Act, so long as the said Schedules stood unaltered, it should be presumed that the legislature did not intend a Labour Court to exercise its jurisdiction in cases where there was a serious question of closure of an establishment put forward by the employers.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: scope of s. 25-FFF of the Act. By issues 6 and 7 the appellant raised questions as to whether the closure had resulted in the retrenchment of the appl

arguments.court_reasoning: Lay-off not in Third Schedule; Second Schedule item 6 covers; precedents confirm s.33C(2) jurisdiction for disputed rights

arguments.claim: Company's liability commences only after 1st October 1960 when it started running the mill

anchor.surface_text: Appearing for the appellant in Civil Appeal No. 2136/66 Mr. Pai contended that his clients liability would only commence after the 1st October, 1960 when it started to run the mill.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: arily unemployed and was number to be entitled to wages during such unemployment except to the exten

arguments.court_reasoning: Point not canvassed before High Court

arguments.claim: Quantum of compensation governed by Standing Orders 19 and 21, not full Chapter V-A

anchor.surface_text: The last point urged was that in view of Standing Orders 19 and 21 the quantum of compensation had to be scaled down or measured in terms of the Standing Order 19 the employer could, in the event of fire, breakdown of machinery etc. stop any machine or machines or department or departments wholly or partially or the whole or a part of the establishment for any period, without notice and without compensation in lieu of notice.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: nch of five, Judges including S. C. Roy, J. who expired a few days back. The above judgment was companycurred in by our late companyleague. We however

arguments.court_reasoning: s.25J provides Chapter V-A overrides inconsistent standing orders

arguments.claim: There was lay-off within s.2(kkk); entitled to compensation for full 18 months except badli workers

anchor.surface_text: The Labour Court held by order dated February 29, 1964 that there had been a lay-off within the meaning of s. 2 kkk  of the Industrial Disputes Act and that the employees were entitled to compensation for the full period of 18 months but workers who were badli workers were not entitled to such compensation.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e appellants in both the appeals preferred writ petitions before the High Court-of Bombay for quashing the order of the Labour Court. The two writ pet

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court affirmed lay-off no closure; remanded for s.25E(ii) evidence

arguments.claim: Running industry by indications, no closure; compensation under s.25C but consider s.25E presentation; badli not entitled; not limited to Standing Orders

anchor.surface_text: Before the High Court four main points were raised... On the first question the High Court held that by every indication and circumstance and by express declaration of its management it was a running industry, meaning thereby that there was no closure. On the second question, the High Court held that the Labour Court should have considered whether the workmen had proved that they had presented themselves for work or not in terms of S. 25-E... It also held that badli labour were not entitled to lay-off compensation. It turned down the contention that compensation was claimable only in terms of the Standing Orders of the Mill.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: scope of s. 25-FFF of the Act. By issues 6 and 7 the appellant raised questions as to whether the closure had resulted in the retrenchment of the appl

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court affirms no closure, jurisdiction, Chapter V-A applies

arguments.claim: s.33C(2) Labour Court has jurisdiction to determine incidental disputes like existence of lay-off right even if disputed

anchor.surface_text: We find ourselves unable to accept Mr. Guptes contention. ... the Labour Court was within its jurisdiction to entertain the applications ... The claim under S. 33-C 2  clearly postulates that the determination of the question about computing the benefit in terms of money may, in some cases, have to be preceded by an enquiry into the existence of the right and such an enquiry might be held to be incidental to the main determination which has been assigned to the Labour Court by sub-s.  2 .

arguments.claim: Lay-off not expressly covered in Schedules; falls under Second Schedule item 6 for Labour Court

anchor.surface_text: Lay-off is not expressly covered by either of the two Schedules. It would therefore be a matter covered by the Second Schedule under item 6 thereof. ... The Third Schedule contains 11 items of which item 10 reads Retrenchment of workmen and closure of establishment.

arguments.claim: Precedent in Central Bank v. Rajagopalan: s.33C(2) covers disputed existing rights; individual vs collective

anchor.surface_text: The ambit of s. 33-C has been examined by this Court on a number of occasions and reference may usefully be made to some of the authorities in this connection ... in Central Bank of India Ltd. v. P. S. Rajagopalan the legislative history of s. 33-C was gone into at length ... s. 33-C 2  takes within the purview cases of workmen who claimed that the benefit to which they are entitled should be computed in terms of money, even though the right to the benefit on which their claim is based is disputed by their employers.

arguments.claim: Notices indicate temporary lay-off not closure; business continuing as some departments worked

anchor.surface_text: The notices which we have referred to can only lead to the above conclusion. The Labour Courts jurisdiction could not be ousted by a mere plea denying the workmans claim to the computation of the benefit in terms of money ... In our opinion the High Courts conclusion that In fact the business of this Company was continuing. They in fact continued to employ several employees. their notices say that some portions of the mills would continue to work was unexceptionable.

arguments.claim: Distinguishes U.P. Electric and Ramakrishna cases; observations not binding or inapplicable

anchor.surface_text: Reference was however made to the decision of U.P. Electric Supply Co. v. R. K. Shukla ... These observation cannot be considered binding on us as all the aspects were not placed before the Court then. Reference was also made to the case of Ramakrishna Ramanath ... In our view, the observations in this case do not help the appellants before us.

arguments.claim: Precedent in Savatram Mills: lay-off compensation under Chapter V-A via s.33C even against State Act contention

anchor.surface_text: In Sawatram Mills v. Baliram the claim of the workmen for lay-off ... this Court held that Compensation for lay-off could only be determined under Chapter V-A of the Industrial Disputes Act and the workmen were entitled under s. 3 3 C  to go before the Second Labour Court to realise moneys due from their employers under Chapter V-A.

holdings.text: The Labour Court has jurisdiction under s.33C(2) of the Industrial Disputes Act to entertain applications for computation of lay-off compensation, including incidental determination of whether there was lay-off or closure.

anchor.surface_text: We find ourselves unable to accept Mr. Guptes contention. We may in this connection refer to the relevant provisions in the Act. The authorities under the Act are specified in different sections of Chapter II containing ss. 3 to 9. Under s. 7 it is open to the appropriate Government by notification in the Official Gazette constitute one or more Labour Courts for the adjudication of industrial disputes relating to any matters specified in the Second Schedule and for performing such other functions as may be assigned to them under the Act. ... the Labour Court was within its jurisdiction to entertain the applications

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.33C(2) allows enquiry into existence of right as incidental to computation; lay-off under Second Schedule item 6 (not Third Schedule closure); precedents like Central Bank affirm jurisdiction over disputed rights; number of claimants does not convert to collective dispute.

holdings.text: There was a lay-off within s.2(kkk), not closure, as business continued with some departments working and notices indicated temporary stoppage.

anchor.surface_text: The notices which we have referred to can only lead to the above conclusion. The Labour Courts jurisdiction could not be ousted by a mere plea denying the workmans claim to the computation of the benefit in terms of money ... In our opinion the High Courts conclusion that In fact the business of this Company was continuing. They in fact continued to employ several employees. their notices say that some portions of the mills would continue to work was unexceptionable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notices showed temporary impracticability until repairs, not permanent stoppage; folding/workshop continued; damage insignificant relative to mill value; transfer of mill indicates ongoing business.

holdings.text: Lay-off falls under Second Schedule item 6 for Labour Court jurisdiction, not Third Schedule item 10 (closure) for Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: Lay-off is not expressly covered by either of the two Schedules. It would therefore be a matter covered by the Second Schedule under item 6 thereof. ... The Third Schedule contains 11 items of which item 10 reads Retrenchment of workmen and closure of establishment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of Schedules; lay-off not listed in Third; item 6 residual for Labour Court.

holdings.text: Provisions of Chapter V-A (including lay-off compensation under s.25C) override inconsistent Standing Orders per s.25J.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rightly turned down the contention in view of S. 25-J of the Act under which the provisions of Chapter V-A are to have effect notwithstanding anything inconsistent therewith contained in any other law including Standing Orders made under the Industrial Employment Standing Orders Act, 1946.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of s.25J override clause.

holdings.text: s.33C(2) applies to individual statutory rights under Chapter V-A even if disputed and numerous claimants; does not require collective dispute or s.10 reference.

anchor.surface_text: in Central Bank of India Ltd. v. P. S. Rajagopalan the legislative history of s. 33-C was gone into at length ... s. 33-C 2 takes within the purview cases of workmen who claimed that the benefit to which they are entitled should be computed in terms of money, even though the right to the benefit on which their claim is based is disputed by their employers.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent in Central Bank: s.33C(2) for disputed existing rights; individual vs collective distinction; legislative intent for speedy individual remedies.

holdings.text: C.P. and Berar Industrial Disputes Settlement Act does not bar claims under Central Industrial Disputes Act for lay-off compensation.

anchor.surface_text: In Sawatram Mills v. Baliram the claim of the workmen for lay-off ... this Court held that Compensation for lay-off could only be determined under Chapter V-A of the Industrial Disputes Act and the workmen were entitled under s. 33 C to go before the Second Labour Court to realise moneys due from their employers under Chapter V-A.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent in Sawatram Mills directly on point against State Act bar.

precedents.citation: Central Bank of India Ltd. v. P. S. Rajagopalan 1

anchor.surface_text: in Central Bank of India Ltd. v. P. S. Rajagopalan 1  the legislative history of s. 33-C was gone into at length and the conclusion of this Court on the scope thereof was as follows  see p. 150  The legislative history to which we have just referred clearly indicates that having provided broadly for the investigation and settlement of industrial disputes on the basis of collective bargaining, the legislature recognised that individual workmen should be given a speedy remedy to enforce their existing individual rights, and so inserted s. 33-A in the Act in 1950 and added s. 33-C in 1956.

precedents.case_name: Central Bank of India Ltd. v. P. S. Rajagopalan
precedents.cited_proposition: legislative history and scope of s. 33-C(2) of Industrial Disputes Act; Labour Court can enquire into existence of right and compute benefit even if disputed; for enforcing existing individual rights speedily without collective adjudication under s.10
precedents.cited_holding: s. 33-C(2) takes within purview cases where benefit computed in terms of money even if right disputed; incidental enquiry into right allowed

anchor.surface_text: Following the above decision, it was held in Mining Engineer Rameshwar 1  that sub-s.  2  of s. 33-C was number companyfined to cases arising under an award, settlement or even under the provisions of Chapter V-A of the Act and the benefit provided in the bonus scheme under the Coal Mines Provident Fund and Bonus Schemes Act, 1948 would be companyered by sub-s.  2 . Section 25-C provides for the measures of companypensation to be awarded in cases of lay-off of workers.

precedents.cited_proposition: s. 33-C(2) not confined to awards, settlements or Chapter V-A; covers benefits under other statutes like bonus scheme under Coal Mines Provident Fund and Bonus Schemes Act, 1948

precedents.citation: U.P. Electric Supply Co. v. R. K. Shukla 1

anchor.surface_text: Reference was however made to the decision of U.P. Electric Supply Co. v. R. K. Shukla 1  in aid of the companytention for the appellants that if the dispute touches a matter in the Third Schedule the Labour Court will number have jurisdiction to. deal with it. In this case the State Electricity Board, P. took over the undertaking of the companypany from September 16, 1964 in exercise of power under sec. 6 of the Indian Electricity Act, 1910 and under the provisions of the appellants licences.

precedents.case_name: U.P. Electric Supply Co. v. R. K. Shukla
precedents.cited_proposition: if dispute touches matter in Third Schedule like retrenchment/closure, Labour Court has no jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: Reference was also made to the case of Ramakrishna Ramanath Presiding Officer, Nagpur 2 . In that case the appellant bad  1  1970 1 S-C.R. 507. 7-L643 Sup. CI/72  2   1970  2 L.L.J. 306. issued a numberice in writing on the 1st July 1958 following the issue of a numberification by the Government of Bombay under S. 5  2  read with s. 5 1  of the Minimum Wages Act, 1948 to the effect that it had been forced to close its factory as from the 1st of July 1958 by the action of the Bombay Government in issuing the said numberification inasmuch as minimum rates of wages made payable as from 1st July, 1958 were so excessive and unworkable that it was impossible for any employer to give effect to them and the numberification had made the working of the business a financial impossibility.

precedents.case_name: Ramakrishna Ramanath v. Presiding Officer, Nagpur
precedents.cited_proposition: dispute on retrenchment/closure due to government notification on wages; jurisdiction of Labour Court vs Tribunal; whether closure or lock-out/lay-off

anchor.surface_text: In Sawatram Mills v. Baliram 1  the claim of the workmen for lay-off during a certain period before the Second Labour Court Bombay was resisted inter alia on the ground that the said companyrt had numberjurisdiction as the dispute fell to be tried under the C.P. and Berar Industrial Disputes  Settlement  Act, 1947, and, secondly, the application under s. 33-C was incompetent because it was number a claim for money due and calculations had to be made for ascertaining the sum due.

precedents.cited_proposition: Labour Court has jurisdiction under s.33C(1) for lay-off compensation under Chapter V-A; Industrial Disputes Act applies over state act even if state act silent on lay-off compensation
precedents.cited_holding: Compensation for lay-off could only be determined under Chapter V-A; workmen entitled to approach Labour Court under s.33C

precedents.citation: Kays Construction Co.  P  Ltd. v. State of U.P. ors.

anchor.surface_text: The other argument was rejected following the judgment in Kays Construction Co.  P  Ltd. v. State of U.P. ors. In substance the point urged by the appellants was that if a claim is made on the basis of a lay-off and the employer companytends that there was numberlay-off but closure, it is number open to a labour companyrt to entertain an application under s. 33-C 2 .

precedents.case_name: Kays Construction Co. (P) Ltd. v. State of U.P. & ors.
precedents.cited_proposition: applicability of Industrial Disputes Act over state industrial disputes act

justification_sets.label: Chapter V-A Industrial Disputes Act support

anchor.surface_text: We find ourselves unable to accept Mr. Guptes contention. We may in this connection refer to the relevant provisions in the Act. The authorities under the Act are specified in different sections of Chapter II containing ss. 3 to 9. Under s. 7 it is open to the appropriate Government by notification in the Official Gazette constitute one or more Labour Courts for the adjudication of industrial disputes relating to any matters specified in the Second Schedule and for performing such other functions as may be assigned to them under the Act. ... the Labour Court was within its jurisdiction to entertain the applications
In the result, the appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.

The Labour Courts jurisdiction could not be ousted by a mere plea denying the workmans claim to the computation of the benefit in terms of money ... In our opinion the High Courts conclusion that In fact the business of this Company was continuing. They in fact continued to employ several employees. their notices say that some portions of the mills would continue to work was unexceptionable.
In the result, the appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.
